article: It was ugly. It was, in fact, the worst Chrismas present I had ever received. I quickly _ to be delighted. After all, the giver was Michael, my four-year-old son, who had _ the distasteful item at his school's Christmas bazaar . "I bought it for you Mama,"he _ yelled, offering it up to me, arms outstretched, face beaming, eyes big, blue and bright. At his young age, he had _ way of knowing that this cheap-looking thing, was the antithesis of all I _ about Christmas decor . And did I mention that it was ugly? Really, really ugly! "We'll...put it...here...on...on the ...kitchen table,"I _ said. The rest of the house was decorated with beautiful, _ materials from the garden. And each year, I demonstrated unique and attractive ways to bring the outdoors _ with creative decorating ideas. How awkward and out of place my son's addition looked in the midst of all this natural beauty. He must have noticed my _ with decorating and thought I would be pleased with such a gift. Soon my older children _ through the back door, excited to relay the _ of their day and display their precious purchases. Within _ , the kitchen table was piled with crude snacks: "Where are the rest of the things you bought?"I turned and asked Michael, _ he hadn't eaten the snacks at school or on the way home. "I spent all my money on your present,"he said proudly, not the least bit _ by the chatter and delight floating in the air as the others _ their booty . Suddenly, this ugly, boring gift took on a new _ . "You spent all your Christmas bazaar money on me?"I asked, unconvinced that a four-year-old boy would _ candy and cupcakes and things designed to _ kids in order to buy a present for his mom. Ugliness _ blossomed into beauty. I was delighted. No. Overjoyed. Wholeheartedly, I hugged both my son and his gift.
